The Satires of Persius are here joined with those of Juvenal, according to a common practice. But except lor the convenience of publication, there is no ‘reason why they should be so. United they form a fair-sized volume, which separately they would not do except by extending the notes on either to an inordinate and useless length. Persius, though older than Juvenal, yet, as being less read and of less importancc, is usually and rightly put after him.

It is easy to write long notes on such authors as these3 indeed

the difficulty is to write atmoderate length3 even without the prac- tice, which I think objectionable, of overlaying the text with an embarrassing heap of references. Among other ways of lengthening this commentary was one which to some general readers would have been acceptable. Ἰ might have dwelt upon the immorality of the age, and contrasted the practice of the heathen with the contem-

porary precepts of the Christian. But I do not think any observa- tions of mine would have strengthened the language of Juvenal,

and if I bave helped Christiana to read and understand him, I shall be satisfied. They will be able then to compare the profligaey of the degenerate Roman with the purity of the Christian’s profession, and perhaps may find in the rehukes of the Satirist matter for more usefrrl contemplation than that which dwells upon the vices and superstitious of former ages, and overlooks the vices and super- stitione of our own. ¹
